Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Convergence of Research at the Interface of the Biological, Physical, and Engineering Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to Yale University, located in New Haven, CT, will support the training of eight students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2015- 2017. The program focuses on grand challenges in the life sciences using physical and quantitative approaches. The program includes more than twelve Yale faculty mentors from nine departments: Applied Physics, Biomedical Engineering, Cell Biology, Chemical & Environmental Engineering, Mechanical Engineering & Materials Science, Molecular Biophysics & Biochemistry, Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology, Pathology, and Physics. In consultation with the program leadership, students choose a mentor and research project from three areas: (A) mechanics of cellular processes, (B) protein function, design, and engineering, and (C) technology and method development for imaging biological systems and processes. Students also participate in workshops on laboratory methods, scientific presentations, ethics, STEM careers, and the graduate school admissions process. Students present their work at a research symposium coordinated with the NSF-funded CRISP REU program at Yale. Students are selected based on their academic performance, research interests that mesh with those of the REU program, and their interest in STEM careers.

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and will be encouraged to present their results at scientific conferences. The program's professional development activities will include oral and poster presentation workshops, information sessions on the graduate application process, and outreach activities that involve communicating science to the general public. A significant goal of the program is that by year 3 at least two thirds of the participants will have decided to pursue a PhD or MD/PhD after graduation from college. Thus, this program will contribute directly to the development of a STEM workforce.

Students that participate in this program are required to be tracked after completion of the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available at http://www.sackler.yale.edu/summer.htm, or by contacting the PI (Prof. Corey O'Hern at corey.ohern@yale.edu) or co-PI (Prof. Lynne Regan at lynne.regan@yale.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 10 week summer NSF REU Site: “Convergence of Research at the Interface of the Biological, Physical and Engineering Sciences” provided hands-on research experiences for undergraduates interested in pursuing graduate studies in science and engineering and careers in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM).  Program participants received mentoring from faculty members, graduate students and postdocs, and REU program staff to allow them to perform high-impact, cutting edge research at the interface of biology, physics and engineering, and develop transferrable professional skills.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Participants entered our REU Site with a variety of majors, including physics, biology, biochemistry, neuroscience, biomedical engineering, mechanical engineering, mathematics, and chemistry. The REU program focused on helping students understand how quantitative approaches and tools from physics and engineering are used to advance biological research. The three specific research themes of the site were 1) mechanics of cellular processes, 2) protein function, design, and engineering, and 3) technology and method development for imaging biological systems and processes. By conducting research in one of these three focus areas, students gained a unique perspective on how theoretical and computational research is combined with wet-lab experiments and what some of the challenges are that scientists face when working on a project that bridges multiple disciplines. The exposure to such a broad range of research topics helped participants decide what area of research they are most interested in pursuing. During the project period, eight manuscripts, with REU participants as co-authors, have been published.

 

Broader Impacts:

A total of 28 undergraduates (13 from underrepresented groups) participated in the program over the three-year project period, most coming from four-year institutions without STEM PhD programs and often without access to state-of-the-art equipment present at large research institutions. Enrichment program activities included a series of workshops and symposia to improve communicating science to interdisciplinary audiences and understand how wet-lab experiments, computation and theory are combined to address grand challenges in biology, science outreach events to excite middle school students about interdisciplinary research, and a series of workshops, panel discussions, and other events to help REU participants learn about the PhD and MD/PhD application process and how to prepare competitive applications, as well as introduce them to a variety of STEM careers. REU students also learned about ethical conflicts that scientists face and had many opportunities to network with researchers within the Yale community. Of the 28 participants, 5 (18%) are still pursuing their Bachelor’s degrees, 13 (46%) are applying to or pursuing a PhD or MD/PhD, 3 (11%) are applying to or pursuing medical school, and 6 (21%) are in a STEM job. This REU Site has and will contribute to the growth and diversification of the STEM workforce.
